result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

10:30 AM Defendant Matthew J McMillan in court with attorney Angela Wang.  Chelsea Thompson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Attorney Wang states she had recent contact with the defendant and indicated he would be late.  Attorney Wang does not have an objection to the State's witness being released and if the defendant appears later today getting a new preliminary hearing date.  State motions the Court to issue a warrant for the defendant and to revoke and forfeit any bail.  Attorney Wang is asking for the Court to stay a capias.  The Court will revoke and forfeit bail and the capias will be stayed until noon.  If the defendant appears prior to noon, the Court will admonish the defendant, reinstate bail, and set a new preliminary hearing date.

Hearing on May 17, 2022 at 01:00 pm.

Defendant to comply with I.D. Processing.  Absolute sobriety, defendant is not to possess or consume any alcohol.  Defendant is not to enter any premises, other than a grocery store, that sells/serves alcohol beverages by the drink or into any liquor store.  Defendant is not to use/possess any controlled substances without a valid prescription and take as prescribed.  Defendant not to possess any drug paraphernalia. Defendant not to use or possess any personal identifying information other than their own, including financial transaction cards.
